item.dc:creator: Amy Buzhardt
item.description: Sample some of the best whiskey and wings in Colorado at the 5th Annual Whiskey and Wings BBQ Festival. Fill your stomach with a variety of styled and flavored wings from local and Front Range restaurants. As your taste-testing to find your favorite make sure you help us pick the best wings around during the... View Article
item.content:encoded: Sample some of the best whiskey and wings in Colorado at the 5th Annual Whiskey and Wings BBQ Festival. Fill your stomach with a variety of styled and flavored wings from local and Front Range restaurants. As your taste-testing to find your favorite make sure you help us pick the best wings around during the Ultimate Sampling Showdown where the Best Wings and the Best Grilled Foods are yours for the judging! If you show up more thirsty than hungry, sample shots of some of the world’s best brands of Whiskey, including some great ones you’ve never heard of! Be adventurous! Try something new! (Must be 21 and over for whiskey sampling. ID required.)

item.title: High Altitude Flamethrowers Chili Fest
item.dc:creator: Amy Buzhardt
item.description: The High Altitude Flamethrower’s Chili Festival is going to be extra hot this year! Trust us; you’re not going to need any extra layers to keep you warm this August weekend.  It’s our annual tradition to host chili chefs throughout the state as they compete in this Colorado State Chili Cook-Off Championship. With the winners... View Article
item.content:encoded:
The High Altitude Flamethrower’s Chili Festival is going to be extra hot this year! Trust us; you’re not going to need any extra layers to keep you warm this August weekend.  It’s our annual tradition to host chili chefs throughout the state as they compete in this Colorado State Chili Cook-Off Championship. With the winners getting a spot to go to the World Competition and a Grand County Champion to be named as well, there will be no shortage of excellent chili sampling. The High Altitude District Championship will be held on Saturday with the Colorado State Championship taking place on Sunday.

There 3 categories include:
Red Chili
Green (Verde) Chili
Salsa

Admission is FREE and you can buy taste tickets at the event!

item.title: Colorado Freeride Festival
item.dc:creator: Amy Buzhardt
item.description: July 23-31, 2016 – Trestle® Bike Park Whether you’re obsessed with mountain biking, just falling in love with riding a bike, or want to witness those who love to be obsessed with riding their bike – you’re invited to the largest freeride festival in the United States at the nation’s premier bike park. Between laps... View Article
item.content:encoded:
July 23-31, 2016 – Trestle® Bike Park

Whether you’re obsessed with mountain biking, just falling in love with riding a bike, or want to witness those who love to be obsessed with riding their bike – you’re invited to the largest freeride festival in the United States at the nation’s premier bike park. Between laps at Trestle Bike Park or after checking out the massive expo area, you’ll experience the world’s best mountain bike athletes and those just beginning their path to being the best. With free family activities such as the Family Bike Fest in the Village at Winter Park, product demos, meet and greets with the athletes, and more in the Festivillage, this is an event you don’t want to miss.

Events Schedule:

Wednesday, July 27: Training (Slopestyle only)
Thursday, July 28: Air Downhill; Maxxis Slopestyle Training; New Belgium Super Downhill Prologue
Friday, July 29: FAMILY DAY – New Belgium Super Downhill; Maxxis Slopestyle Training & Qualifications; Green Horn-it! Challenge; Pump Track Challenge; Family Bike Fest in the Village at Winter Park
Saturday, July 30: Epic Singletrack XC; Maxxis Slopestyle Finals; Intergalactic Pond Crossing; Family Bike Fest in the Village at Winter Park
Sunday, July 31: USAC State Championship Downhill; Banana Peel Jam

For more info on what Colorado Freeride Festival is all about click here:http://coloradofreeridefestival.com/index.html

item.title: Chocolate Festival
item.dc:creator: Amy Buzhardt
item.description: Chocolate, chocolate, and you guessed it…more chocolate!! The 7th annual Chocolate Festival is the ultimate opportunity to celebrate all things CHOCOLATE! Treat yourself to multiple samples while enjoying live music and entertainment throughout the day. This event is a treat for any Winter Park Resort vacationer and a destination for chocolate lovers around the state!... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Chocolate, chocolate, and you guessed it…more chocolate!! The 7th annual Chocolate Festival is the ultimate opportunity to celebrate all things CHOCOLATE! Treat yourself to multiple samples while enjoying live music and entertainment throughout the day. This event is a treat for any Winter Park Resort vacationer and a destination for chocolate lovers around the state! Admission is free to the public. Guests may purchase “Taste Tickets” to get multiple samples. Here is a tentative schedule of events for the day:

Event Schedule:

  • 10:00 am- Festival opens with Live Music
  • 11:00 am- Chocolate Pudding Eating Contest; enter to win a Golden Ticket worth $10 at any booth (rounds for adults and kids)
  • 12:00 pm- Name That Chocolate; win a Golden Ticket worth $10 at any booth
  • 1:00 pm- Chocolate Crown Competition; who can eat the most Hershey Kisses in one minute (enter to win the coveted crown made entirely of edible chocolate)
  • 2:00 pm – Chocolate Making Demo
  • 4:00 pm – Festival closes

For more information visit the event website or Facebook page.

Shri Fest is a yoga and arts festival that celebrates life in all its beauty. It brings together a community of like-minded people in an atmosphere infused with creativity and wonder.

item.title: July 4th Celebration
item.dc:creator: Shaun Kerr
item.description: For over 100 years Steamboat Springs has celebrated Independence Day in real Colorado fashion. Where else can you find a celebration that includes three days of ski jumping? The Jumpin’ and Jammin’ Competition on July 4th gives a nod to Steamboat’s Olympic heritage, and events like the Pioneer Days Block Party, featuring a free concert... View Article
item.content:encoded:
For over 100 years Steamboat Springs has celebrated Independence Day in real Colorado fashion. Where else can you find a celebration that includes three days of ski jumping? The Jumpin’ and Jammin’ Competition on July 4th gives a nod to Steamboat’s Olympic heritage, and events like the Pioneer Days Block Party, featuring a free concert and Root Beer Floats for the kids, and the Ranch Rodeo where local ranches compete against one another, are proof Steamboat’s western roots are alive and well.

This is a special holiday and Steamboat does it right with a hometown parade which ends in a big dance party in the street. Don’t miss the pancake breakfast, take a float down the Yampa River to cool off, and head over to one of the biggest nights of the summer Pro Rodeo Series. After the rodeo, keep your seat and watch the sky fill up with the beautiful colors of one of the biggest firework shows in Colorado.

For full schedule, click here.

item.content:encoded:
The Fourth of July parade in Steamboat Springs is one of the highlights of Cowboys’ Roundup Days. The parade begins at 10:00am in downtown Steamboat on Lincoln Ave. but you’ll want to be downtown early to find a good seat.

Afterwards, head over to the Pioneer Day Block Party on the corner of 8th and Oak streets for food, fun and Routt Beer Floats, or head over to the Jumpin’ & Jammin’ Ski Jumping Competition starting at noon.

The event includes a vintage and warbird static aircraft display, classic cars, kids activities, and back for the second year, a high-flying aerobatic show! You can get in on the action too by booking a plane ride, or... View Article
item.content:encoded:
The Wild West Air Fest is a feature of the Labor Day weekend celebration in Steamboat Springs. The event includes a vintage and warbird static aircraft display, classic cars, kids activities, and back for the second year, a high-flying aerobatic show!

You can get in on the action too by booking a plane ride, or take the kids for some hands-on fun in the Kids Zone. Whatever you choose, don’t miss this family-friendly weekend in Steamboat.

Visit www.wildwestairfest.com to learn more about the Wild West Air Fest.

item.title: 35th Steamboat Marathon
item.dc:creator: Shaun Kerr
item.description: Run alongside the roaring Elk River through the emerald green pastures on Country Road 129 with the snow-capped Rocky Mountains of Colorado all around and find out why the Steamboat Marathon was ranked as one of the “Top 10 Destination Marathons in North America.” “The Steamboat Marathon is a unique combination of beautiful scenery and... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Run alongside the roaring Elk River through the emerald green pastures on Country Road 129 with the snow-capped Rocky Mountains of Colorado all around and find out why the Steamboat Marathon was ranked as one of the “Top 10 Destination Marathons in North America.”

“The Steamboat Marathon is a unique combination of beautiful scenery and extraordinary people, which makes this race fun for everyone who participates,” says Paul Sachs, the Steamboat Marathon Race Director. “Runners from all over the country look forward to the Steamboat Marathon because it is still a relatively small race with a hometown feel and it’s a race where every runner counts.”

All races start at 7:30am.

Click here to register. The Steamboat Marathon is part of the Steamboat Springs Running Series.

item.title: Balloon Rodeo and Art in the Park
item.dc:creator: Shaun Kerr
item.eventLocation: 2305 Mt. Werner Circle Steamboat Springs, CO 80487
item.description: The Hot Air Balloon Rodeo and Art in the Park weekend is one of the most colorful weekends in Colorado. Get to the launch grounds early to see the balloons inflate. The rodeo portion of the event consists of dipping the balloon baskets into Bald Eagle Lake, and since balloon pilots can be pretty competitive,... View Article
item.content:encoded:
The Hot Air Balloon Rodeo and Art in the Park weekend is one of the most colorful weekends in Colorado.

Get to the launch grounds early to see the balloons inflate. The rodeo portion of the event consists of dipping the balloon baskets into Bald Eagle Lake, and since balloon pilots can be pretty competitive, you’re guaranteed a good show.

Watch more balloons dot the Yampa Valley sky, then get ready to head to Art in the Park. On the west side of town you can visit with more than one hundred-forty artist and culinary vendors showcasing a variety of work, catch some live entertainment, and let the kids enjoy the interactive art area.

For more detailed information click here.

Balloon Launch Location

Approximately 9/10 of a mile south of Walton Creek Road on Highway 40, 35565 South Highway 40 and the property is better known as the Bald Eagle Lake.

Parking

Free transportation is provided from the free Meadows Parking lot on Pine Grove Road. Due to the event’s convenient location on the edge of town, we encourage spectators to walk, ride their bikes or take the shuttle from the hotel or lodge.

*No dogs are allowed at event site due to balloon hazards. Thank you!

item.description: More than 400 Mustang owners from Rocky Mountain Mustang clubs will convene in Steamboat Springs, Colorado over Father’s Day Weekend. Activities will include a scenic mountain tour, auto cross, Friday night social, Show n’ Shine Car Show and awards breakfast. Spectators are welcome at the Meadows parking lot located at the corner of Mt. Werner... View Article
item.content:encoded:
More than 400 Mustang owners from Rocky Mountain Mustang clubs will convene in Steamboat Springs, Colorado over Father’s Day Weekend. Activities will include a scenic mountain tour, auto cross, Friday night social, Show n’ Shine Car Show and awards breakfast.

Spectators are welcome at the Meadows parking lot located at the corner of Mt. Werner Road and Pine Grove Road for Friday’s Autocross. Over 180 Ford Mustangs compete in this timed event. Saturday’s Show n’ Shine is a car lovers dream, with over 400 Ford Mustangs on display up and down Lincoln Avenue for your viewing pleasure.

Both events are free and open to the public.

item.title: Routt County Riders Day
item.dc:creator: Shaun Kerr
item.eventLocation: 2305 Mt. Werner Circle, Steamboat Springs, CO 80487
item.description: The Routt County Riders are a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization and International Mountain Biking Association (IMBA) Chapter club that continues to grow and represent more variations of biking, including downhill/freeride, year-round commuting, and adaptive cycling. The local chapter is a volunteer-based, membership-driven organization that offers input to and through numerous governmental agencies including CDOT, Northwest Transportation... View Article
item.content:encoded:
The Routt County Riders are a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization and International Mountain Biking Association (IMBA) Chapter club that continues to grow and represent more variations of biking, including downhill/freeride, year-round commuting, and adaptive cycling. The local chapter is a volunteer-based, membership-driven organization that offers input to and through numerous governmental agencies including CDOT, Northwest Transportation Region, U.S. Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, Routt County, the City of Steamboat Springs, the Emerald Mountain Partnership, and others.

Each year a sponsorship day is held at the Steamboat Bike Park to benefit the Routt County Riders trail maintenance fund. Tickets price is TBA (season bike passes are not valid on this day) and available for use 3:00 to 7:00pm. Visit the Steamboat Bike Shop to purchase tickets and rentals.

• Bike Park Access: TBA (season bike passes are not valid)
• Scenic Gondola Ride: TBA
• Coca-Cola Adventure Zone: 50% off for all day pass and individual tickets
• Rentals: 50% off bike rentals

STEAMBOAT BIKE PARK

The Steamboat Bike Park will be open daily from Friday, June 9 through Sunday, August 26, then Friday evenings until 6:00pm in September.

SCENIC GONDOLA RIDES

The Steamboat gondola is open from 10:00am – 4:00pm. Last download by 4:30pm. Sundays will open at 9:30am. Gondola tickets are valid all day, weather permitting.

The gondola will operate for Steamboat Bike Park access, Thursday and Friday until 7:00 pm. (June 9 through August 26), and for food and beverage facility access and special events.

Tickets are available at the Ticket Office open 9:00am to 4:00pm, or at the gondola entrance after 4:00pm when gondola operates for public access. Call 970-871-5255 for group sales – special pricing is available for pre-arranged groups of 25 or more.

Tickets also available at the Information Center open 9:00am to 5:00pm (open until 7:00pm, Thursday and Friday, June 12 through August 28).

item.title: Program Offerings
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: Vision Statement To inspire lifelong enjoyment of sport Mission Statement To provide high quality opportunities which promote lifelong enjoyment of sport Program Philosophy The philosophy of the Winter Park Competition Center is to offer the opportunity to achieve ones’ highest potential as an athlete, person, and competitor. Through the enjoyment of sport, each athlete’s commitment,... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Vision Statement

To inspire lifelong enjoyment of sport

Mission Statement

To provide high quality opportunities which promote lifelong enjoyment of sport

Program Philosophy

The philosophy of the Winter Park Competition Center is to offer the opportunity to achieve ones’ highest potential as an athlete, person, and competitor. Through the enjoyment of sport, each athlete’s commitment, desires, dreams and failures, can provide significant life lessons. We consider the athlete first, winning second, as we strive to develop the total athlete. This goal is affected by the objectives each competitor has in participation in the program and by his/her personal motivation. Those factors, applied to the most supportive coaching and training environment we can offer, helps athletes to develop a positive, healthy, and confident attitude – the most important aspect of the total athlete. We believe that the total athlete will not only be a successful skier or rider, but excel in all aspects of life with those skills. Cornerstones to our efforts are self-motivation, effort, and commitment. An individual’s success in snow sport competition is directly dependent on his/her approach to these areas.

item.title: Sports Performance Program – Nutrition
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: INTRO – Why is it important ATHLETE NUTRITION ·         Check out Team USA for guidance in achieving your nutritional goals!  Here you’ll find information on: http://www.teamusa.org/About-the-USOC/Athlete-Development/Sport-Performance/Nutrition/Resources-and-Fact-Sheets ·         Sample athlete plates ·         Nutrition while traveling ·         Reading food labels ·         Recovery nutrition ·         Breakfast fuel ·         Healthy recipes ·         Tips for the vegetarian athlete    ... View Article
item.content:encoded:
INTRO – Why is it important

ATHLETE NUTRITION

·         Check out Team USA for guidance in achieving your nutritional goals!  Here you’ll find information on: http://www.teamusa.org/About-the-USOC/Athlete-Development/Sport-Performance/Nutrition/Resources-and-Fact-Sheets

·         Sample athlete plates

·         Nutrition while traveling

·         Reading food labels

·         Recovery nutrition

·         Breakfast fuel

·         Healthy recipes

·         Tips for the vegetarian athlete

                                                                                HYDRATION  

You might have a “water mom” or “water dad” if you have said…

“I have a headache”

“I can’t sleep”

“I’m tired”

“The dog ate my homework”

…and your parent has responded with, “DRINK MORE WATER!”

Our body simply cannot survive without water and we cannot perform at our athletic peak if dehydrated. “Gee coach, I always have a sip of water when I feel thirsty”. Unfortunately, thirst is not a good indicator of hydration level. In fact, our body is already dehydrating by the time we feel thirsty.

What Every Athlete Should Know About Hydrating

  • Water will enhance your athletic performance.
  • How do I know if I am hydrated? As a guideline, check the color of your urine. A little gross and cool at the same time! Very light or clear colored urine means that you are doing a good job at staying hydrated. Light or darker colored urine means that it’s time to have some water.
  • Exactly how much water should I be drinking each day? This will depend on your body size and what types of activity you are engaged in. You may have heard to drink 8 – 10 glasses/day or to divide your body weight (in pounds) by two and drink that amount in ounces (e.g., if you weigh 120 lbs., drink 60 oz. of water each day. Either method will help you to establish the minimum amount of water you should have each day.
  • Compared to adults, younger athletes are at greater risk of dehydrating.
  • Try to drink beyond your level of thirst.
  • Is water my only choice? No. The foods that we eat and other beverages contain water. Diluted fruit juices and non-caffeinated teas are good choices, especially if you have trouble drinking plain water. Even your chocolate milk recovery drink contains water.
  • When you know the location of every public restroom between your house and the ski area, you are drinking enough water!
  • Suggested Water Intake Guidelines 
  • Drink two or more glasses with breakfast, lunch and dinner.
  • Have a glass of water at snack time.
  • Drink two glasses of water before and after training.
  • Drink at regular intervals during training. This means that you should have a water bottle on the hill!
  • Drink beyond just quenching your thirst.
  • Drink water every 20 minutes during exercise (yes – training is exercise!).Energy drink and soda have no place on your training table!Sport drinks generally contain electrolytes (like sodium and potassium) and carbohydrate. Electrolytes help the body to distribute water, are important for muscle contraction and nerve signaling, and help move carbohydrate (i.e., glucose) to muscle. The typical Western diet contains plenty of sodium whereas a well-balanced diet will provide adequate potassium.
  • Foods high in potassium include:
  • Are Sport Drinks OK?
  • What About Energy Drinks?
  • Avocado
  • Baked Potato (with skin)
  • Banana
  • Beans
  • Beef
  • Breads
  • Dark Leafy Greens
  • Fish
  • Milk and Yogurt
  • Mushrooms
  • Orange Juice
  • TomatoWarning Signs of Dehydration
  • Sport drinks tend to help most during activities lasting over one hour. In snow sport competition, most athletes won’t benefit from using a sport drink on event day. However, you might try a sport drink or powder mix (e.g., Skratch Labs, Emergen-C) on training days.
  • Feeling weak or tired
  • Feeling irritable (tough to know parents!)
  • Flushing of the cheeks
  • Dry or chapped lips; constant lip licking
  • Restlessnesshttp://www.healthychildren.org/english/healthy-living/nutrition/Pages/default.aspx
  • Resources:
http://www.usada.org/resources/nutrition/fluids-and-hydration/

item.title: Sports Performance Program – Injury Return To Sport
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: The Return to Sport Program’s goal is to facilitate an injured athlete’s journey through rehabilitation and recovery and a successful return to sport.  Injury can come with a lot of frustrations, emotions, and changes, and the RTS Team is here to help.  Some of the areas focused on include: Social support (coping with feelings of... View Article
item.content:encoded:
The Return to Sport Program’s goal is to facilitate an injured athlete’s journey through rehabilitation and recovery and a successful return to sport.  Injury can come with a lot of frustrations, emotions, and changes, and the RTS Team is here to help.  Some of the areas focused on include:

  • Social support (coping with feelings of isolation from the team/sport they love)
  • Fear or re-injury
  • Staying motivated throughout physical therapy
  • Handling stress (skiing can be a stress reliever, and with injury, that coping mechanism goes away, sometimes causing changes in mood, behavior, eating/sleeping habits, etc.)Preferred Providers:Middle Park Medical Center Physical Therapy, Granby Office 970-887-5851 http:// www.mpmc.org/services/physical-therapy-granby/
  • Boulder Bone and Joint 1032 South 88th Street Louisville, CO 80027 http://boulderboneandjoint.com
  • To get involved in the RTS program (as an athlete or a coach!), or to find out more, email Stephanie Zavilla at szavilla@winterparkresort.com.

item.title: Sports Performance Program – Sports Psychology
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: WHAT IS SPORT PSYCHOLOGY: WHAT IS SPORT PSYCHOLOGY: Sport Psychology can be summed up in a few simple ideas: It allows us to navigate the pressures, obstacles, pitfalls, and emotional ups and downs of elite sport effectively and efficiently Through mental skills training, we can become aware of the interplay between our physiological system and... View Article
item.content:encoded:
WHAT IS SPORT PSYCHOLOGY:

WHAT IS SPORT PSYCHOLOGY:

Sport Psychology can be summed up in a few simple ideas:

  • It allows us to navigate the pressures, obstacles, pitfalls, and emotional ups and downs of elite sport effectively and efficiently
  • Through mental skills training, we can become aware of the interplay between our physiological system and psychological and emotional factors
  • Learning how to think in the most effective way possible in every day, every competition, and every situation
  • Building better athletes, but more importantly, building highly functional mentally strong human beings
  • We work on developing skills such as:
  • Focus, concentration, allocation of attention
  • Confidence
  • Self-motivation
  • Overcoming obstacles, handling pressure
  • Self-talk
  • Imagery, visualization

Plainly stated, mental skills training and sport psychology provides the opportunity for athletes to discover the power they have within themselves, and the ability to use it when it matters most.

WHY IS IT IMPORTANT:

·         An athlete can be in the best shape of their life, trained their bodies to perform, but if they show up on competition day and cannot control their mind, none of it matters

Sport psychology is becoming a central piece of elite athletics – From professional teams and athletes to the U.S. Olympic Training Center, training the MIND is becoming an essential piece of performance enhancement

BIOFEEDBACK

Winter Park Competition Center is now on the cutting edge of sport science with the introduction of Heart Rate Variability Biofeedback training protocols.  This training is helpful in a number of ways:

·         Athletes receive instantaneous feedback demonstrating the mind-body connection

·         It allows us to assess an athlete’s ability to handle stress, as well as how quickly they can bring their physiology back to baseline

It offers the opportunity to train the body to adapt to stress

HOW WE WILL ADDRESS IT:

Although mental skills training has been a part of the Sports Performance Program since its inception, Winter Park Competition Center believes in sport and performance psychology enough to invest in a full-time program, keeping pace, if not far surpassing most elite youth sport organizations.  By incorporating cutting edge developments and technology, and staying up to date on current research, the Comp Center will be at the forefront of new performance enhancing ideas and methodology.

Through this program you will have access to various levels of training:

·         Group sessions

·         Individual consultation

·         On-hill training integration

·         Parent education workshops

·         Coaching education clinics

·         Group and individual sessions for part-time athletes on the front range

·         Heart Rate Variability Biofeedback technology

ABOUT OUR MENTAL SKILLS COACH: 

Stephanie Zavilla completed her Master’s degree in June of 2013 at the University of Denver’s Graduate School of Professional Psychology in Sport and Performance Psychology.  She completed her undergraduate course work at the University of South Dakota, receiving a Bachelor of Science in both Psychology and History, with a minor in Business Administration. Through playing NCAA Division I golf while at the University of South Dakota, she fell in love with the mental side of sport and performance.

During her time at the University of Denver, she has worked with many sports and organizations on both a group and individual basis. Her primary internship field placement was served with Ski and Snowboard Club Vail and Vail Ski and Snowboard Academy as a Peak Performance Mental Skills Intern.  Other experience includes sports such as basketball, synchronized figure skating, soccer, agility training, tennis, and exercise adherence, as well as some clinical issues (i.e. life transitions, depression, anxiety), and has worked with individuals and teams ages 9 through 50+.

Stephanie’s philosophy revolves around the idea that simply by being aware, being present, and being in love with what you do, athletic freedom will follow; freedom from judgmental thoughts, freedom from the constraints of internal and external pressures, and most importantly, freedom of movement. Through self-reflection and exploration, any athlete can take their performance from good to great, especially when it really counts.

Stephanie’s contact information:

szavilla@winterparkresort.com, office: 970-726-1678, cell: 303-917-2481
RESOURCES:

For athletes:

http://appliedsportpsych.org/ Go to “Resource Center” to access valuable information for Coaches, Parents, and Athletes, as well as Injury/Rehabilitation and Health and Fitness!

For coaches:

http://positivecoach.org/ Go to “Our Tools” to check out resources for Parents, Athletes, Coaches, and Leadership roles!

Here at the Competition Center, we believe that becoming a great athlete is about more than just putting in the time and effort on the hill, but that there is a science behind optimal performance. That is why we have assembled a team of highly qualified experts to facilitate our athletes as they pursue excellence in both sport and in life. We encourage you to use this section of the website as a RESOURCE to guide you towards accomplishing your goals!

Check out our blog to stay current on new trends in strength and conditioning , sports psychology, and getting the most out of your training: wpccsportperformance.wordpress.com.

Please contact Stephanie Zavilla, Director of Sports Performance, with any questions or comments!

item.title: Volunteer Opportunities
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: Ski or Ride for Free Program We rely on great event workers to consistently produce the best mountain biking events in the summer and the best ski and snowboard events in the winter. Many of our workers keep coming back year after year to take advantage of the benefits, like front row seats for some... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Ski or Ride for Free Program

We rely on great event workers to consistently produce the best mountain biking events in the summer and the best ski and snowboard events in the winter. Many of our workers keep coming back year after year to take advantage of the benefits, like front row seats for some of the most exciting competitions anywhere, with competitors ranging from blossoming juniors and seasoned masters, to world-class athletes. And of course… the free lift tickets!!

As a worker you can earn as many vouchers for lift tickets as you want. Work for a day, or on a regular basis throughout the season. For every five hours you work, you earn a one day lift ticket which can be used by you, your friends, or family.

Winter Season 2015-2016 – Find out about current volunteer opportunities through the SignUp Genius Website.  http//www.signupgenius.com/

To receive important volunteer information newsletters, click here.

View Article
item.content:encoded:
Winter Park Ski Education Foundation

The Winter Park Ski Education Foundation (WPSEF) was established in 1987 as a 501(c) (3) non-profit charitable organization. It is run by a board of volunteers so all funds raised go to:

  • Support the training of athletes and competitors in Alpine, Freestyle, Freeski, All-Terrain and Snowboard programs through the Winter Park Competition Center.
  • Develop, maintain and support the sport of ski and snowboarding competition.
  • Support entry-level programs for each of the above-mentioned areas.
  • Assist athletes, young and old, reach their potential and possibly fulfill their dreams of becoming a world-class competitor or even an Olympic champion. The Grand Foundation Donor Advised Funds – G.A.P. (Grand Activities and Programs) Fund for Grand County Kids
  • To apply for assistance download the 2015-2016 Scholarship Application

item.content:encoded: Location: Lower level Balcony House left of the exterior ticket office 970.726.5514 ext. 1809. The Competition Center Workshop provides precision ski tuning, waxing, and mounting services at the best possible prices for Competition Center members and their families. The shop also sells all tuning equipment, waxes, and Competition Center logo wear. Racing accessories (pole guards, shin guards, etc.) are also available. Hours are 8:30am-4:30pm on weekdays and 8:00am-4:30pm on weekends and holidays during the season. Purchases made at our ski repair shop benefit our ski and snowboard programs. Unfortunately, due to space constraints, we are unable to offer snowboard tuning and waxing services but the shop does carry a selection of snowboard parts in case of equipment malfunction. Contact the Snowboard Program Director for in-town tuning recommendations.

item.description:  AGES 10+ Register ATP includes training 1 day per week and is offered on Saturdays or Sundays. ATP Short groups do not meet President’s weekend February 12-14. Program length: 10 weeks, 9am- + 3:15pm with a 45 minute lunch break (lunch is not provided and is unsupervised). Saturday program: Saturdays, Jan 9, 2016 through Mar. 19,... View Article
item.content:encoded:
 AGES 10+

Register

ATP includes training 1 day per week and is offered on Saturdays or Sundays. ATP Short groups do not meet President’s weekend February 12-14.

Program length: 10 weeks, 9am- + 3:15pm with a 45 minute lunch break (lunch is not provided and is unsupervised).

Saturday program: Saturdays, Jan 9, 2016 through Mar. 19, 2016 Sunday program: Sundays, Jan 10, 2016 through Mar. 20, 2016

Make-up days will not be offered

The All Terrain Short Program (ATP Short) is a 10-week program designed to challenge black diamond skiers in the trees, steeps, and powder.  It is geared toward skiers aged 10 and up who cannot commit to the full 15-week All Terrain Program.  Emphasis is placed on skill development on Winter Park’s most difficult terrain in a fun, high energy environment with some of the Competition Center’s best coaches.

This is an excellent program for ATP Devo, Team Discovery, and Freestyle Devo team skiers who are looking to continue skiing at a high level but aren’t pursuing racing or freestyle competition. It is also a great next step for older Eskimo and Ski and Ride School program skiers. Skiers will be exposed to big mountain skiing, adjusting techniques and tactics for steep terrain and variable snow conditions.

ATP Short also offers Holiday Camp (Dates TBD). Athletes may participate in any, all, or none of the camp days. Camp is an informal chance to ski with a different coach and meet other kids in the program. This is also a great opportunity to ski before the program start date.

COST: 1-day program: $1055* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. Subtract $130 if you already have a pass. Select Saturday or Sunday for the full season. -*$100 late fee applies after 10/15/15 for returning families.

Resources FAQ About ATP Competition Center Handbook 15-16 Phillip “Toad” Pittz |All Terrain Program Director| ppittz@winterparkresort.com

 AGES 10+

Register

ATP includes training 1 day per week and is offered on Saturdays or Sundays. ATP groups do not meet on Christmas weekend December 25th-27th (but are invited to attend Holiday Camp, see below) or President’s weekend February 13th-15th.

Program length: 15 weeks, 9am- +3:15pm with a 45 minute lunch break (lunch is not provided and is unsupervised).

Saturday program: Saturdays, Dec. 5th, 2015 through Mar. 26th, 2016 Sunday program: Sundays, Dec. 6th, 2015 through Mar. 27th, 2016

Make-up days will not be offered

The All-Terrain Program (ATP) challenges black diamond skiers in the trees, steeps, and powder.  It is geared toward skiers aged 10 and up.  Emphasis is placed on skill development on Winter Park’s most difficult terrain in a fun, high energy environment with some of the Competition Center’s best coaches.

This is an excellent program for ATP Devo, Team Discovery, and Freestyle Devo team skiers who are looking to continue skiing at a high level but aren’t pursuing racing or freestyle competition. ATP is also a great next step for older Eskimo and Ski and Ride School program skiers. Skiers will be exposed to big mountain skiing, adjusting techniques and tactics for steep terrain and variable snow conditions.

ATP is not  an introductory ski program.  Participants must come to the program already with the ability and desire to ski at a high level.  Athletes without the required skill set may be asked to transfer to another WP ski program or be offered a prorated refund.

ATP also offers Holiday Camp December 26th – 28th. Athletes may participate in any, all, or none of the camp days. Camp is an informal chance to ski with a different coach and meet other kids in the program.

COST: 1-day program: $1255* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. Subtract $130 if you already have a pass. Select Saturday or Sunday for the full season. -*$100 late fee applies after 10/15/15 for returning families.

Resources FAQ About ATP Competition Center Handbook 15-16

Phillip “Toad” Pittz | All Terrain Director | ppittz@winterparkresort.com

item.content:encoded:
Ages: 6-12

Register

ATP Devo includes training 1 day per week and is offered on Saturdays, or Sundays. ATP Devo does not meet on Christmas weekend December 25th–27th or President’s weekend February 13th-15th.

Program length: 14 weeks, 9am- + 3:15pm

Saturday program: Saturdays, Dec. 5th, 2015 through Mar. 19th, 2016 Sunday program: Sundays, Dec. 6th, 2015 through Mar. 20th, 2016

Make-up days will not be offered

Hot lunch (supervised) is included

The All Terrain Development Program (ATP Devo) is a 14-week ski program geared toward skiers aged 6 to 12 who are of intermediate ability or higher.  Skiers will be exposed to freestyle, park & pipe, racing and all-mountain skill sets. Groups of roughly eight children of similar age and ability will work closely with an expert Competition Center coach toward skill improvement.  Competition opportunities will be provided but are not required.

The All Terrain Development Program is a great first step to other Competition Center programs in alpine or freestyle or to continue on in the ATP program. Our focus is to create lifelong skiers while learning to ski the whole mountain in all conditions.

Prior to participation in this program:

-At a minimum, skiers should be able to get on and off the lift unassisted and be able to stop and make wedge turns on blue terrain.

-Skiers who do not meet these requirements or cannot commit to a 14-week program should consider one of the Ski and Ride School’s shorter multi-week programs.  Click here for more information about Ski and Ride School programs.

COST: $1155* – includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. Subtract $130 if you already have a pass. Select Saturday or Sunday for the full season.  -*$100 late fee after 10/15/2015 for returning families.

Resources FAQ About ATP 

Competition Center Handbook 15-16

Phillip “Toad” Pittz | All Terrain Director | ppittz@winterparkresort.com

item.title: All Terrain Adult Program
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: Register Are your kids skiing faster than you? Then ski with the Competition Center’s most experienced coaches in a casual format designed for breakthroughs in skiing moguls, crud, and all variable snow conditions. This is a program that will explore the mountain at your pace accomplishing your skiing goals. Get ready to take advantage of... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Register

Are your kids skiing faster than you? Then ski with the Competition Center’s most experienced coaches in a casual format designed for breakthroughs in skiing moguls, crud, and all variable snow conditions. This is a program that will explore the mountain at your pace accomplishing your skiing goals. Get ready to take advantage of new overnight snow, or maybe new tactics in a NASTAR course, because we’ll be skiing All Terrain!

Not a Parent? Not a problem! Join the Adult All Terrain Program for a true all-mountain experience. Don’t plateau; go downhill!

Dates:   Session 1- Saturdays or Sundays  Jan 10 thru Feb 8

Session 2- Saturdays or Sundays Feb 20/Feb 21 thru Mar 19/Mar 20

Cost:  $300/session, $500 for both. You can do a drop-in sampler on Jan 10 & Feb 21 $50/day, subtracted from session fees if then enrolled. Season pass not included. Drop-in on a Saturday and/or Sunday $80/day no lift access included

Phillip “Toad” Pittz | All Terrain Program Director | ppittz@winterparkresort.com

AGES 8+

Register

The WPST Short Program is a 12-week program designed for athletes who are unable to commit to a full-season program, but still have a passion for snowboarding and want to progress in their riding! Like our full season programs, athletes will select to focus on either All Mountain or Park + Pipe programs during registration.

AGE/ABILITY EXPECTATIONS:

  • must be 8 years old by 12/31/2015.
  • must be proficient linking short radius (tight) toe and heel side turns on blue-black terrain.
  • must demonstrate proper stance and edging techniques on blue terrain.
  • riders should be ready and willing to start working on riding switch (unnatural).
  • riders who do not meet these requirements or who cannot commit to a full-season program should consider a Ski and Ride School (SRS) multi-week program. Click here for more info on SRS programs.

item.title: Winter Park Snowboard Team Park + Pipe
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: AGES 8+ Register  The WPST Park + Pipe program is a full-season program designed with the avid park rider in mind. Park + Pipe program participants will spend most days in any of Winter Park Resort’s six terrain parks and superpipe, honing their freestyle shred skills! Park + Pipe riders are encouraged to participate... View Article
item.content:encoded:
AGES 8+

Register

 The WPST Park + Pipe program is a full-season program designed with the avid park rider in mind. Park + Pipe program participants will spend most days in any of Winter Park Resort’s six terrain parks and superpipe, honing their freestyle shred skills!

Park + Pipe riders are encouraged to participate in slopestyle and halfpipe competitions. Riders will have the opportunity to hone their competitive strategies in local, regional, and national halfpipe and slopestyle competitions. Local events include the King of the Grommets slopestyle events, while regional and national level competitors attend USA Snowboard Association (USASA) events at resorts around the state. WPST coaches work with each rider to determine what events to attend based on ability, age, interest, goals, and maturity/sportsmanship.

WPST athletes competing in the USASA regional series are encouraged to sign up for the 2-day, 3-day, or Full-Time program.

AGE/ABILITY EXPECTATIONS:

  • Must be 8 years old by 12/31/2015.
  • Must demonstrate proper stance and edging techniques on advanced terrain.
  • At minimum, riders should be able to ride switch at half of one’s speed when riding regular, with the goal of being able to ride forward and switch the same speed and with consistent stance and edging.
  • Riders who do not meet these requirements or who cannot commit to a full-season program should consider a Ski and Ride School (SRS) multi-week program. Click here for more info on SRS programs.

DATES & TIMES:

  • 1-day Park + Pipe: Dec. 5, 2015 thru April 9, 2016. Select Fri, Sat, or Sun program for the full season. 9am-3:30pm.
  • 2-day Park + Pipe: Nov. 21, 2015 thru April 9, 2016 Select Fri/Sat; Sat/Sun; or Fri/Sun for the full season. 9am-3:30pm.
  • 3-day Park + Pipe: Nov. 20, 2015 thru April 9, 2016. Meets Fri, Sat, & Sun. 9am-3:30pm.COST: The WPST Park + Pipe weekend program is offered 1, 2, or 3 days on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.
  • *see full calendar for camp dates and scheduled days off.
  • 1-day Park + Pipe: $1405* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass.
  • 2-day Park + Pipe: $2080* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass.
  • 3-day Park + Pipe: $2395* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass
  • There is an additional work deposit fee of $200 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer hours. Click here for details.Team Jacket for the upcoming 16-17 season (For athletes in a 2 or 3 day program only) Enroll by October 15th to secure your team jacket size.WPST 1-day does not practice President’s weekend Feb 12-14. WPST Team Resources  Competition Center Handbook 15-16 USASA Rocky Mountain Series Events and Schedules 15-16 USSA Snowboarding
  • Nic Nagel | Snowboard Director and Head Coach | email Nic
  • WPST 2-day, 3-day, and Fulltime do practice over President’s weekend to keep on-point for USASA competitions.
  • WPST Park + Pipe program fees include the WPST Holiday Camp Dec. 27th through Dec. 30th.

item.title: Winter Park Snowboard Team Fulltime
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: FULLTIME ACADEMY Register The WPST Full-Time program is designed for those athletes who have demonstrated a high level of dedication to snowboarding and competing in USASA competitions and who want to take their riding to the next level. Full-time athletes exhibit the drive and desire to pursue high level events such as the USSA Revolution Tour... View Article
item.content:encoded:
FULLTIME ACADEMY

Register

The WPST Full-Time program is designed for those athletes who have demonstrated a high level of dedication to snowboarding and competing in USASA competitions and who want to take their riding to the next level. Full-time athletes exhibit the drive and desire to pursue high level events such as the USSA Revolution Tour and USSA Grand Prix events, whether they are ready for these events immediately or have ambitions to compete in these events in the future. WPST coaches work with each rider to determine what events to attend based on ability, age, interest, goals, and maturity/sportsmanship.

During the winter season, full-time athletes ages 11-13 (middle school) are on-hill from 1-4pm on Tues/Thurs and are on-hill 9-3:30 F/Sa/Su, with supervised study/athletic science programs on Wednesdays. Full-time athletes ages 14+ (high school/post-grad) are on-hill 1-4pm T-W-Th and 9-3:30 on F/Sa/Sun.   All Full-time athletes are expected to participate in camp, workshop and training opportunities provided through the Competition Center’s Athletic Science program during the season.  Off-season activities (e.g. summer camp) are strongly encouraged but are not included in program cost (April 13-Oct. 31).

AGE/ABILITY EXPECTATIONS:

  • The full-time program is open to middle and high school students, as well as college-age athletes.
  • Full-time participants must be in 6th grade or higher to participate.
  • Must demonstrate proper stance and edging techniques on advanced terrain (all mountain and in the parks/pipe), riding both switch and regular.
  • Must have been competing in USASA events for at least one season.
  • Athletes interested in being considered for the Fulltime Academy are required to complete and submit the Fulltime Academy application to Nic Nagel, WPST Director at nnagel@winterparkresort.com.Full-Time Park + Pipe: Nov. 1, 2015 thru April 10, 2016. Meets Tues – Thurs from 1-4pm; Fri, Sat, & Sun. 9am-3:30pm.COST:WPST Fulltime: Middle School $3630* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass; access to Grand Park Rec Center for Competition Cneter guided fitness activities; Sports Science program and directed workouts during the week. High School $4330* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass; access to Grand Park Rec Center for Competition Center guided fitness activities; Sports Science program and directed workouts during the week.* $100 late fee after 10/15/2015.WPST 2-day, 3-day, and Full-Time train over President’s weekend to keep on-point for USASA competitions.Nic Nagel | Snowboard Director and Head Coach | email Nic
  • WPST Team Resources  USASA Rocky Mountain Series USSA Snowboarding
  • Team Jacket for the upcoming 16-17 season Enroll by October 15th to secure your team jacket size

  • WPST Full-Time program fees covers all training days and includes coaching at all events. Competition-related expenses such as lodging, transportation, entry fees, and food are not included in the program fee. If needed, transportation and lodging are coordinated by the WPST Director; however, it is the responsibility of the athlete/athlete’s family to register on-time for events and to plan for meals during training and events.

item.title: Winter Park Snowboard Team All Mountain
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: AGES 8+ Register WPST All Mountain programs are for snowboarders who want to ride a variety of terrain, particularly hitting up the groomers, bumps, trees, steeps and powder on Winter Park and Mary Jane! The All Mountain program is also a great option for riders who think they may be interested in terrain park riding... View Article
item.content:encoded:
AGES 8+

Register

WPST All Mountain programs are for snowboarders who want to ride a variety of terrain, particularly hitting up the groomers, bumps, trees, steeps and powder on Winter Park and Mary Jane! The All Mountain program is also a great option for riders who think they may be interested in terrain park riding but who want to own their all mountain skills prior to joining a Park + Pipe program.

Although competition is not required, participants who are interested in exploring competition are welcome to compete at Winter Park Resort’s King of the Grommets slopestyle series and/or the Competition Center’s internal Big Mountain competitions. King of the Grommets is held in the Re-railer terrain park and the Big Mountain events are typically held in the Mary Jane Chutes or Vasquez Cirque These competitions are focused on fun and getting a taste of what snowboard competition is all about!

AGE/ABILITY EXPECTATIONS:

  • Must be 8 years old by 12/31/2015.
  • Must be proficient linking short radius (tight) toe and heel side turns on blue-black terrain.
  • Must demonstrate proper stance and edging techniques on blue terrain.
  • Riders should be ready and willing to start working on switch riding (unnatural direction).
  • Riders who do not meet these requirements or who cannot commit to a full-season program should consider a Ski and Ride School (SRS) multi-week program. Click here for more info on SRS programs.
  • DATES & TIMES:
  • 1 day All Mountain(Choose Friday, Saturday or Sunday): Dec. 4, 2015 thru April 8, 2016 – From 9am – 3:30pm.
  • 2 day All Mountain: Nov. 21, 2015  thru April 9, 2016 – From 9am – 3:30pm.
  • 3 day All Mountain: Nov. 20, 2015 thru April 10, 2016 From 9am – 3:30pm.COST:
  • The WPST All Mountain program is offered 1 or 2 days per week on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays.
  • *see full calendar for camp dates and scheduled days off.
  • 1-day All Mountain: $1405* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass.  Select either Fri, Sat, or Sun for the full season.
  • 2-day All Mountain: $2080* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. Select Fri/Sat, Sat/Sun, or Fri/Sun for the full season.
  • 3-day All Mountain: $2395* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. *There is an additional work deposit fee of $200 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer hours. Click here for details.        *$100 late fee after 10/15/2015. WPST All Mountain program fees include the WPST Holiday Camp Dec. 27th through Dec. 30th. WPST All Mountain does not meet President’s weekend February 12-14.Nic Nagel | Snowboard Director and Head Coach | email Nic

item.title: Winter Park Snowboard College Team
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: AGES 18+ Register WPST College Team for riders ages 18 and up! We understand how hectic life can be after high school, whether you’re in school or working full-time. With that in mind, we’ve created this flexible program to keep you stoked, progressing and having a rad time with like-minded riders! The WPST College Team... View Article
item.content:encoded:
AGES 18+

Register

WPST College Team for riders ages 18 and up! We understand how hectic life can be after high school, whether you’re in school or working full-time. With that in mind, we’ve created this flexible program to keep you stoked, progressing and having a rad time with like-minded riders! The WPST College Team is focused on Park + Pipe riding, especially geared towards riders wanting to compete in USASA and some USSA events.

What’s included? Program fees include a Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass and 6 flexible days of training. Flexible training means you can select days to ride with WPST based on what works with your school schedule, shredding with friends and/or a collegiate team, and competition schedules.

6 days not enough? No worries! You can either add indvidual days for a daily rate OR sign up for one of our full season programs (1-day, 2-day, 3-day, or Full-Time). We know balancing school and shred is difficult, so college riders participating in our full season programs can work with the program director in scheduling what days to ride with the team.

How are training groups decided? Training groups are determined first by skill, goals, and maturity, thus groups ultimately consist of a variety of ages.

Please contact WPST Director NIC NAGEL with any questions!

DATES & TIMES:

WPST College Team: Nov. 29, 2015 thru Apr. 5, 2016. Contact WPST Director NIC NAGEL to set up training days. Fri/Sat/Sun: 9am-3:30pm. May drop into Thursday training (1-4pm) for $25.

COST:

WPST College Team fees cover 6 training days. Athletes can choose whether to use their days for at-home training and/or for coaching at events. Competition-related expenses such as lodging, transportation, entry fees, and food are not included in the program fee. If needed, transportation and lodging are coordinated by the WPST Director; however, it is the responsibility of the athlete to register on-time for events and to plan for meals during training and events.

WPST College Team: $810* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. additional drop-ins: $40 for full-day, $20 for Thursday. Must be coordinated at least 3 days in advance (e.g. contact Nic on Wednesday to join the team on Saturday).

* *$100 late fee after 10/15/2015.

WPST College Team athletes may choose to use some of the 6 days during the WPST Holiday Camp Dec. 27th through Dec. 30th. The WPST College Team does not offer training New Year’s Day, or President’s weekend (unless preparing for USASA/USSA)

WPST Team Resources  Competition Center Handbook 15-16 USASA Rocky Mountain Series Events and Schedules 15-16 USSA Snowboarding

Nic Nagel | Snowboard Director and Head Coach | email Nic

item.title: Water Ramping for Freestyle and Freeski Athletes
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: 2016 Water Ramp Camps at Steamboat And Utah Olympic Park (UOP) – Sign-Up Now!! Steamboat Join us for any or all of our single or multi-day ramp camps at Bald Eagle Lake in Steamboat Springs. Our days begin with a light warm up and then some trampoline work on the facility’s in-ground tramps. When we... View Article
item.content:encoded:
2016 Water Ramp Camps at Steamboat And Utah Olympic Park (UOP) – Sign-Up Now!!

Steamboat

Join us for any or all of our single or multi-day ramp camps at Bald Eagle Lake in Steamboat Springs. Our days begin with a light warm up and then some trampoline work on the facility’s in-ground tramps. When we are warmed up and ready to go, we get geared up and hit the ramps until athletes are too tired, cold, and/or hungry to jump any more. Then, we generally sit by the lake and enjoy the beauty of our awesome state, and eventually get geared up for a second session of jumping in the afternoon.

Directions: As you approach Steamboat Springs from Rabbit Ears Pass, you will go by Haystack golf course, and the left hand turn for highway 131. Just past the storage facility on your left, the road widens, and right as the middle lane begins, you will see the left-hand turn in to Bald Eagle Lake. This is a private water ski lake, and the owner is generous enough to donate use of his land and lake for this very unique ski training. Please obey posted speed limits on the road (10 mph). The ramp facility is at the very end of the Bald Eagle Lake access road. Park in the parking lot after the wooden bridge, before you drive up over the hill to the ramps. If you bring your dog, please leave it in the parking lot, as they are not allowed by the lake.  What to bring: Ski boots, old skis (they won’t slide well on snow after they slide on the ramp surface), helmet (with ear covers), PFD, sunscreen, lots of water or sports drink, picnic lunch, and a great attitude. Wetsuits or drysuits are recommended, and will greatly increase both your ramper’s comfort level and length of sessions.

To Download and to Register for the Steamboat Water Ramp Sessions Click Here

Utah Olympic Park (UOP) July 17-22

Check out this cool link to the new construction at UOP http://utaholympiclegacy.org/park-web-cam/

To Download and to Register for the UOP Water Ramp Sessions Click Here

item.title: Telemark Program
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: AGES 8+ Register The Telemark Team challenges experienced telemark skiers with carving, moguls, tree skiing, steeps, park, and powder.  This 16-week program is geared toward skiers ages 8 and up. Emphasis is placed on skill development on Winter Park’s advanced terrain in a fun, high energy environment.  Skiers will gain confidence and skill at free-heel... View Article
item.content:encoded:
AGES 8+

Register

The Telemark Team challenges experienced telemark skiers with carving, moguls, tree skiing, steeps, park, and powder.  This 16-week program is geared toward skiers ages 8 and up. Emphasis is placed on skill development on Winter Park’s advanced terrain in a fun, high energy environment.  Skiers will gain confidence and skill at free-heel skiing, while learning new techniques to become a great all-around telemark skier. Groups with similar abilities will work closely with an expert Competition Center coach to build on existing skills in order to maximize performance and have fun dropping knee on the mountain’s toughest terrain.

DATES:

Saturday program: Dec 6, 2015 through Mar. 19 2016

The Telemark Team trains one day per week on Saturdays. The Telemark Team does not meet over Christmas weekend December 26 or President’s weekend February 12-14.

1-day program: $1255* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass.

-*$100 late fee applies after 10/15/15 for returning families.

Telemark Team Resources Competition Center Handbook 15-16

Contact Phillip “Toad” Pittz | All Terrain/Telemark Director | ppittz@winterparkresort.com

item.title: Alpine Spring Camp 2016
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: We are pleased to announce Spring Camp 2016 At Winter Park/Mary Jane Registration is Open!! Session 1 – May 13-15 Session 2 – May 20-22 Colorado’s ski season is not over!  We are excited to Kick-off the “new” racing season with at home spring camps!  Our focus is on the fundamentals – balance, stance, and... View Article
item.content:encoded:
We are pleased to announce Spring Camp 2016 At Winter Park/Mary Jane

Registration is Open!!
Session 1 – May 13-15
Session 2 – May 20-22

Colorado’s ski season is not over!  We are excited to Kick-off the “new” racing season with at home spring camps!  Our focus is on the fundamentals – balance, stance, and edging drills – and taking it into a variety of terrain and snow conditions.  We will implement our skills training into drill courses and gates. Training will be followed by video and tech talks.  Then the afternoon’s will have optional off-snow programming, including, but not limited to dry-land, field workouts, sport psych sessions, fitness testing.

Possible guest athletes include: Storm Klomhaus, Anna Marno, others TBD

Download the WPK Spring Camp Registration Packet

item.title: June Camp Mammoth Mountain and August Camp Mt.Hood
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: Registration Open!! Mammoth Camp June 11-21 – On-Snow (13-16 And 18-20) Mt. Summer camps are an excellent place for athletes... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Registration Open!!

Mammoth Camp June 11-21 – On-Snow (13-16 And 18-20)

Mt. Hood Camp August 7-17 – On-Snow (9-12 And 14-16)

In the more than twenty years that Team Winter Park has conducted summer camps, we have seen amazing turnarounds in the skiing of our camp participants. Summer camps are an excellent place for athletes to immerse themselves in the sport that they love, without the pressures of racing and school. The environment is more relaxed, the weather is warm, and there is more time to spend on the fundamentals of the sport. There is also time to build stronger relationships with teammates and coaches and to engage in fun activities off the ski hill as well as on-snow. We welcome skiers from other teams to join our camps, and often new friendships develop that last through seasons to come. We encourage you to read about our camps below, and hope you can join us this summer for some great skiing, and more!

Both the Mammoth Mountain and the Mt. Hood Race Departments do an amazing job of providing top notch services such as salt cats to make the snow harder, rolling terrain features to challenge the campers, and giving everyone a space to set course.

Mammoth Camp
The on-snow focus of the Mammoth Camp will be on fundamentals starting outside the course in the free environment. Then the camps will follow a progression that implements the fundamentals into drill courses, course sections and full length courses.
Download the Mammoth Camp registration

Mt. Hood Camp
The on-snow focus of the Mt. Hood Camp will be on technical fundamentals using a number of progressions which emphasize basic stance, balance, edging and pressure.                               Download the Mt. Hood Camp registration

item.title: Freestyle Step 3 Competitive Team
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: AGES 13+ Register The Winter Park Freestyle Team is arguably the strongest team in the country.  Last season, one of our premier athletes, Bruce Perry was named to the US Freestyle Ski Team and participated in his first two World Cups.  We qualified three athletes for Junior World Championships.  Bruce Perry and Casey Andringa unfortunately... View Article
item.content:encoded:
AGES 13+

Register

The Winter Park Freestyle Team is arguably the strongest team in the country.  Last season, one of our premier athletes, Bruce Perry was named to the US Freestyle Ski Team and participated in his first two World Cups.  We qualified three athletes for Junior World Championships.  Bruce Perry and Casey Andringa unfortunately suffered injuries, and were unable to attend.  Joel Hedrick, currently the number one junior in the country, did attend, capturing 4th and 6th places.  Our Nor-Am team is the largest in the country and continues to place athletes on the podium on this demanding tour.  If you are a committed athlete looking to excel in the sport of freestyle moguls, Winter Park is the place to train, boasting a full-length, FIS specification mogul course right at the base December – April, 2 permanent aerial sites, and 3 additional mogul courses on the mountain.

The Freestyle Competitive Team is a competitive program emphasizing the development of technical skills necessary to excel in freestyle skiing. Building a strong technical base for mogul skiing will allow the skiers to perform at their best in the mogul arena. Consistent aerial training on our own aerial or mogul course is incorporated into their training regime for a total freestyle package. State of the art training technology in physical conditioning, sport psychology, video analysis, goal setting and planning assist each athlete on the road to excellence.

Skiers will be grouped according to age and ability and work with a primary coach throughout the season. This is a competitive program and athletes must be willing to put forth a great deal of commitment and motivation to attain their personal best. Freestyle Competitive Team provides three days of training per week for freestyle skiers ages 13 and older. The team takes full advantage of its time on snow by blending free skiing skills with regular training in moguls and freestyle aerials. This team competes on the USSA Freestyle circuit in the Rocky Mountain Division Series in Colorado and USSA JO’s if the athlete qualifies. Athletes looking for extra training opportunities should try our spring trampoline camps, summer water ramp camps, on snow camps and fall conditioning sessions.

AGE & ABILITY EXPECTATIONS: Must be 13 years of age by 12/31/2015. Must be proficient linking short radius turns on blue black and black terrain. Must demonstrate proper stance and edging techniques on blue terrain. Must be ready and willing to start working on aerials skills in the terrain parks, mogul courses and aerial site. All Skiers will need to purchase USSA and RMD competitors license and will compete in their recommended events.

DATES & TIMES: FS Competitive: Nov 21, 2015 thru April 3, 2016. Meets Sat & Sun from 9am-3:30pm; Fridays from 10am-3:30pm.

COST: The Freestyle Competitive program is a 3-day program, which meets Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. Cost: $2525* includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. There is an additional work deposit fee of $400 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer work hours. Click here for details. *$100 late fee after 10/15/2015 for returning families.

Team Jacket for the upcoming 16-17 season Enroll by October 15th to secure your team jacket size.

item.title: Freestyle Step 2 Junior Qualifier Team
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: Register The Winter Park Freestyle Junior Qualifier Team is an exciting addition to the freestyle program offerings. The junior qualifier team is designed to align with the Rocky Mountain Freestyle’s “RQS” competition series as next step from Freestyle Devo and the preparatory program for the Freestyle Competitive Team for athletes ages 11 – 15 (ages... View Article
item.content:encoded:
Register

The Winter Park Freestyle Junior Qualifier Team is an exciting addition to the freestyle program offerings. The junior qualifier team is designed to align with the Rocky Mountain Freestyle’s “RQS” competition series as next step from Freestyle Devo and the preparatory program for the Freestyle Competitive Team for athletes ages 11 – 15 (ages based on the USSA cutoff date: December 31 of that ski season)

Program participants have the opportunity to train in a high-paced, structured environment with qualified and caring coaches. The athletes can expect to ski 100% (or all) of the mountain depending on snow conditions and timing throughout the course of the day: flats, moguls, terrain-park, trees, and steeps with an emphasis on mogul skiing skills. Athletes develop their aerial skills in the terrain parks, on the mogul course and at the freestyle team jump site. Our coaches follow the USSA skill-development season outline to ensure quality training and solid progressions. The athlete can expect to engage in group drills and receive individual feedback based on one’s performance. The coaches give specific feedback highlighting what the athlete executes well and what skiing skills he/she can improve while spending time with each individual setting goals and creating the road map to achieve personal best in sport. As in all Competition Center programs, we put emphasis on our mission, “Lifelong enjoyment of the Sport.”

Must be proficient linking short radius turns on blue black and black terrain. Must demonstrate proper stance and edging techniques on blue terrain. Must be ready and willing to start working on aerials skills in the terrain parks, mogul courses and aerial site. All Skiers will need to purchase USSA and RMD competitors license and will compete in their recommended events. Competition experience strongly recommended

The Freestyle Junior Qualifier Team requires one year of participation in an organized ski program before participating. The program is offered on Saturdays and Sundays and includes coaching at the Rocky Qualifier Series and the Rocky Mountain Freestyle Junior competitions.

Dates: Nov. 21, 2015 through March 27, 2016 and includes the Holiday Camp.  2 Day Program: for athletes ages 11 -15 Saturday, Sunday and competition days is $2130 includes a Winter Park/Mary Jane pass. There is an additional work deposit fee of $400 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer work hours. Click here for details.

Team Jacket for the upcoming 16-17 season (for the 2 day athletes only) Enroll by October 15th to secure your team jacket size.

1 Day Program for athletes ages 11-13 (J4 and first year J3) on Saturday and competition days is $1630 includes a Winter Park/Mary Jane pass. There is an additional work deposit fee of $200 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer work hours. Click here for details.

Freestyle Junior Qualifier Team Resources Competition Center Handbook 15-16 Rocky Mountain Freestyle Event Schedule

item.title: Freestyle Step 1 Development Team
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: AGES 8-14 Register The Winter Park Freestyle Devo Program is the introduction to freestyle and freeskiing and the feeder program for the Junior Qualifier Team, the Junior Freeski Team, and the Big Mountain Team. Athletes ages 8-14 (these ages based on the USSA cutoff date: December 31 of that ski season) have the opportunity to... View Article
item.content:encoded:
AGES 8-14

Register

The Winter Park Freestyle Devo Program is the introduction to freestyle and freeskiing and the feeder program for the Junior Qualifier Team, the Junior Freeski Team, and the Big Mountain Team. Athletes ages 8-14 (these ages based on the USSA cutoff date: December 31 of that ski season) have the opportunity to train in a high-paced, structured environment with qualified and caring coaches. The athletes can expect to ski 100% of the mountain throughout the course of the day: flats, moguls, terrain-park, trees, and steeps (snow dependent). Athletes practice their aerial skills in the terrain parks and at the freestyle team jump site. The coaches follow the USSA skill-development season outline to ensure quality training and solid progressions. The athlete can expect to engage in group drills and receive individual feedback based on one’s performance. The coaches give specific feedback highlighting what the athlete executes well and what skiing skills he/she can improve. The program realizes the importance of the “whole” package when grouping the athletes: age, ability, discipline or area of focus and group dynamics. We put emphasis on our mission, “Lifelong enjoyment of the Sport.” The Devo Program requires one year of participation in an organized ski program before participating. The program is offered on Saturdays and/or Sundays.

FREESTYLE DEVELOPMENT TRAVEL TEAM The Winter Park Freestyle Devo Travel Team is a competitive mogul program for 8-14 year olds (ages based on the USSA cutoff date: December 31 of that ski season). The Devo Travel team is designed to align with the Rocky Mountain Freestyle’s Devo Freestyle competition series as the next step from the noncompetitive Freestyle Devo Program; this travel team is the preparatory program for the Junior Qualifier Team (RQS). Program participants have the opportunity to train in a high-paced, structured environment with qualified and caring coaches. The athletes can expect to ski 100% of the mountain depending on snow conditions and timing throughout the course of the day: flats, moguls, terrain-park, trees, and steeps (snow dependent) with an emphasis on mogul skiing skills. Athletes develop their aerial skills in the terrain parks, on the mogul course, and at the freestyle team jump site. Our coaches follow the USSA skill-development season outline to ensure quality training and solid progressions. The athlete can expect to engage in group drills and receive individual feedback based on one’s performance. The coaches give specific feedback highlighting what the athlete executes well and what skiing skills he/she can improve while spending time with each individual setting goals and creating the road map to achieve personal best in sport. As in all Competition Center programs, we put emphasis on our mission, “Lifelong enjoyment of the Sport.” The Devo Freestyle Travel Team requires one year of participation in an organized ski program before participating. The program is offered on Saturdays and includes coaching at the Rocky Mountain Freestyle Devo competitions.

Team Resources and Manual Competition Center Handbook 15-16 Rocky Mountain Freestyle Event Schedule 

DATES & TIMES:

1-day FS Devo: December 5, 2015 – March 20, 2016. Saturdays or Sundays 8:45am-3:30pm. 2-day FS Devo: December 5, 2015 – March 20, 2016. Saturdays and Sundays 8:45am-3:30pm. Travel Team: December 5, 2015 – March 20, 2016. Meets Saturdays and includes the Holiday Camp (December 26th & 27th And January 2nd & 3rd).

COST: 1-day FS Devo: $1305*, includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. 2-day FS Devo: $1980*, includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass. Travel Team: $1475*, includes the Winter Park/Mary Jane season pass.

* There is an additional work deposit fee of $200 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer work hours. Click here for details.

* $100 late fee after 10/15/2015 for returning families.

Freestyle Devo Team Internal Series When: Saturday, February 13th and Sunday, March 13th The Internal Series is designed to be a fun competition to allow athletes to test their freestyle mogul and jumping skills in a competition setting. We encourage the athletes to set personal goals for the competition so that success is not tied to results. At the Development level, personal accomplishments raise confidence levels and the enjoyment of skiing. The Internal Series is a one-run mogul competition. It is a non-timed, non-licensed (no USSA or Rocky Mountain License) competition, run through the Winter Park’s Competition Center.

The athletes will have time in the morning to inspect and practice on the course before their competition run. This competition also allows the athletes the opportunity to ski hard and cheer on one’s team mates.

Deadline to register for each competition is at 5pm the Friday immediately before the event. The Event Day Fact Sheet (start times, run order, location of awards ceremony) will be available at registration / bib pick-up the morning of the competition.

Cost: $20 per event

Registration is open – Click here for link to registration

item.title: Freestyle Fulltime Academy
item.dc:creator: Sylvie Isaacs
item.description: FULLTIME ACADEMY Register  The Winter Park Freestyle Team is arguably the strongest team in the country.  Last season, one of our premier athletes, Bruce Perry was named to the US Freestyle Ski Team and participated in his first two World Cups.  We qualified three athletes for Junior World Championships.  Bruce Perry and Casey Andringa unfortunately... View Article
item.content:encoded:
FULLTIME ACADEMY

Register 

The Winter Park Freestyle Team is arguably the strongest team in the country.  Last season, one of our premier athletes, Bruce Perry was named to the US Freestyle Ski Team and participated in his first two World Cups.  We qualified three athletes for Junior World Championships.  Bruce Perry and Casey Andringa unfortunately suffered injuries, and were unable to attend.  Joel Hedrick, Junior National Mogul Champion is currently the number one junior in the country, did attend, capturing 4th and 6th places.  Our Nor-Am team is the largest in the country and continues to place athletes on the podium on this demanding tour.  If you are a committed athlete looking to excel in the sport of freestyle moguls, Winter Park is the place to train, boasting a full-length, FIS specification mogul course right at the base December – April, 2 permanent aerial sites, and 3 additional mogul courses on the mountain.

The full-time Freestyle Team is an intensive year-round training program for the freestyle competitor with a total commitment toward reaching their highest goals in competitive freestyle skiing. Skiers train six days a week during the ski season. During the off-season, athletes participate in several summer camps and projects while following a physical training program designed to prepare them for success during the ski season. A highly experienced coaching staff teaches the most current techniques of mogul skiing and aerials using the latest in video technology to help the athletes improve. Off-snow sessions include indoor trampoline sessions, mental skills training, and physical conditioning led by our Sports Performance specialist and Sports Psychologist Director Stephanie Zavilla. (learn more on the sports performance page)

Winter training takes place in the afternoons on Tuesday through Thursday, and all day Friday through Sunday. (East Grand Middle School students train the aforementioned days except for Wednesdays.) Middle school and high school athletes enroll in the East Grand School District where schedules are arranged for core classes to take place in the morning, and student/athletes are transported to the ski area at lunch time for afternoon training. East Grand is on a 4-day school week, so skiers have a full day of training on Friday – it doesn’t get any better!

DATES AND TIMES

Start and end dates: November 3, 2015 – April 10, 2016.   Meets Tuesday-Thursdays 1-4. Saturday-Sunday. 9am-3:30pm

COST: $4430* Includes Winter Park/Mary Jane Pass, access to Grand Park Rec Center for Competition Center guided fitness activities, Sports Science program and directed workouts during the week.  There is an additional work deposit fee of $400 which is refunded upon completion of volunteer work hours. Click here for details.

-*$100 late fee after 10/15/2015 for returning families.

Team Jacket for the upcoming 16-17 season Enroll by October 15th to secure your team jacket size.

Admittance to the Winter Park Competition Center Fulltime Academy (WPCCA) is through an application process. If you are interested in enrolling in the Fulltime Academy program, download the application and send to Laurie Mooney Freestyle and Freeskiing program director at lmooney@winterparkresort.com.
